content.text:
# List of public art in Warwickshire

This is a list of public art in the Warwickshire county of England. This list applies only to works of public art on permanent display in an outdoor public space. For example, this does not include artworks in museums.
Alcester
| show_artist= yes
| artist = Severn Lamb Ltd
| type = Sculpture
| material =
| dimensions =
| designation =
| coordinates =
| owner = Alcester Town Council
| notes = Marks 50 years of peace after the end of the Second World War in 1945. Presented to the town of Alcester by Severn Lamb Ltd. It was erected on the site of the former Globe Hotel.
}}
| show_artist= yes
| artist = Walter Ritchie
| type = Sculpture
| material = stone
| dimensions =
| designation =
| coordinates =
| owner = Alcester Town Council
| notes = There are six panels including a needle and spring, a goose, a Roman soldier, a lady on a horse and a man carrying a heavy sack.
}}
Ansley
| show_artist= yes
| artist = Graeme Mitcheson
| type = Sculpture
| material = Sandstone
| dimensions =
| designation =
| coordinates =
| owner =
| notes = Installed as part of the North Arden Heritage Trail, a Heritage Lottery funded project. Scenes represent Ansley's heritage and natural environment including mining, railways, ribbons, Great Crested Newts, conkers and brooks. The central image is taken from the Norman arch at St Laurence Church and shows a man torn between the dragon and the lamb, represents the struggle of good against evil.
}}
Atherstone
| owner = North Warwickshire Borough Council
| notes = Based on the Shrovetide Ball Game.
}}
Bedworth
| show_artist= yes
| artist = Graham Mitcheson
| type = Sculpture
| material = Stone
| dimensions =
| designation =
| coordinates =
| owner =Nuneaton and Bedworth Borough Council
| notes = Celebrates Bedworth's industrial heritage. Formed to resemble stacked discs of wound ribbon (local ribbon industry), each disc commemorates an industry with a particular significance to Bedworth's past.
}}

| coordinates =

| notes = There is a similar statue to this in Worcester at the Shire Hall.
}}
| show_artist= yes

| material = Bronze
| dimensions =

| coordinates =

| show_artist= yes
| artist =
| type = Sculpture
| material = Metal, painted
| dimensions = 100 centimetres (39 inches) high x 120 centimetres (47 inches) wide, approx.
| designation =
| coordinates =
| owner = Warwick District Council and Royal Leamington Spa Town Council
| notes = Two figures, wearing helmets and fireman's uniforms, are either side of a cart. Moved to Euston Place in 1965. It was the premises on Locke and England. The emblem was previously at 166 Parade when it was 33 Lower Parade (the firm moved there in 1875).
}}

| notes = Also called Lockhart Dancing Elephants. The Three Graces (or Charites) are mythological goddesses of charm, beauty, nature, creativity and fertility.
}}

Stratford-upon-Avon
Town Centre
| show_artist= yes
| artist =  Rob Turner
| type = Mosaic
| material = Unglazed ceramic mosaic tiles
| dimensions = 1.5m in diameter
| designation =
| coordinates =
| owner = Stratford on Avon District Council
| notes = There is five mosaics between Stratford-upon-Avon Station at Station Square and Alcester Road, on Station Approach. Depicts the history of the town. Including: The Cattle Market, Stratford's Historic Spine, The Stratford Canal and River Avon, The original Memorial Theatre and The Riverside Heritage Trail.
}}
| show_artist= yes
| artist =  Jethro Cossins & Robert Bridgeman & Sons of Lichfield
| type = Drinking Fountain
| material = Stone
| dimensions =
| designation = Grade II* listed
| coordinates =
| owner = Stratford on Avon District Council
| notes = Donated to the people of Stratford by George W. Childs (when there was no suitable memorial to Shakespeare in England at the time)
}}
| owner =
| notes = It is on the roof, and can also be seen from the Leisure Centre Car Park
}}
| show_artist= yes
| artist = Fred J Kormis
| type = Statue
| material = Bronze
| dimensions =
| designation =
| coordinates =
| owner =
| notes = 	A statue of a young man in medieval dress supporting a shield. The shield is that of the former Stratford Borough. After the local government reorganisation of 1974 the arms of the former Stratford Borough were transferred by the Earl Marshal to Stratford-upon-Avon Town Council.
}}
| show_artist= yes
| artist = John Cheere
| type = Statue
| material = Lead
| dimensions =
| designation = Grade II listed
| coordinates =
| owner = Stratford District Council
| notes = Given to the town by David Garrick in 1769. Next to Shakespeare is a head with a crown on it. He is pointing down at the school with its right hand. On the scroll is inscribed lines from A Midsummer Night's Dream. The statue was restored in 2022.
}}
| show_artist= yes
| artist =  Louisa Forbes
| type = Statue
| material = Bronze
| dimensions =
| designation =
| coordinates =
| owner = Bell Court
| notes = Puck was influenced by A Midsummer Night's Dream
}}
Bancroft Gardens
| show_artist= yes
| artist = Ronald Gower
| type = Statue
| material = Bronze
| dimensions =
| designation = Grade II* listed
| coordinates =
| owner = Stratford on Avon District Council
| notes = Statue of William Shakespeare surrounded by characters from his plays. Unveiled in 1888. It was outside the Royal Shakespeare Theatre until it burned down in 1926. It was moved to its present site in 1933.
}}
| show_artist= yes
| artist = Lawrence Holofcener
| type = Statue
| material = Bronze
| dimensions =
| designation =
| coordinates =
| owner = Stratford on Avon District Council
| notes = The American artist gave the statue to the town to mark the 400th anniversary of the Bard's death
}}
| show_artist= yes
| artist = John Henry Foley
| type =Statue
| material = Bronze
| dimensions =
| designation =
| coordinates =
| owner = Stratford on Avon District Council
| notes = Cast in bronze by J.A. Hatfield in 1851 for the Great Exhibition. Alfred Bullard donated it to Bancroft Gardens in 1932.
}}
| show_artist= yes
| artist =  Christine Lee
| type = Fountain
| material = Marble and Stainless Steel
| dimensions = 450cm high x 250cm wide x 250cm deep
| designation =
| coordinates =
| owner = Stratford on Avon District Council
| notes = Commemorates the 800th anniversary of the granting of market rights to the town of Stratford-upon-Avon by Richard I.
}}
| show_artist= yes
| artist =   Hornton Quarries, Brent Hayward with Darren Hayward, Trevor Brown and Naomi Hamer.
| type = Sculpture
| material =  Hornton Stone (Limestone with Iron content).
| dimensions = 250cm high x 87cm wide x 23cm deep x other dimensions (irregular shape)
| designation =
| coordinates =
| owner = Stratford on Avon District Council
| notes = Marked 50 years of peace since the end of World War Two in Europe in 1995
}}
Henley Street
| show_artist= yes
| artist = James Butler
| type = Statue
| material = Bronze
| dimensions = 8 foot
| designation =
| coordinates =
| owner = Stratford on Avon District Council
| notes = Donated by local Stratford businessman Tony Bird OBE. Installed in July 2020 on the refurbished Henley Street. The artist made it in 2016 to commemorate the 400th anniversary of the Bard's death but it took four years to find a permanent home.
}}
| show_artist= yes
| artist = James Walter Butler
| type = Statue
| material = Bronze
| dimensions =
| designation =
| coordinates =
| owner = Stratford on Avon District Council
| notes = The character of the jester or fool appears in many of Shakespeare's plays
}}
| show_artist= yes
| artist = Douglas Wain Hobson
| type = Relief
| material = Bronze
| dimensions = 150cm high x 200cm wide x 35cm deep approx.
| designation =
| coordinates =
| owner = Shakespeare Birthplace Trust
| notes = The sculptor intended to represent Shakespeare's greatness.
}}
| show_artist= yes

| material = Bronze
| dimensions =

}}
Rosebird Centre
| show_artist= yes
| artist =
| type = Statue
| material = Bronze
| dimensions =
| designation =
| coordinates =
| owner = Stratford on Avon District Council
| notes = Used to be at the Maybird Centre from the early 1990s until 2013. Tony Bird owner of both the Maybird and Rosebird Centre's had hoped to have the statue relocated to an island, as a gateway to Shakespeare's Stratford. It was installed at the Rosebird roundabout near the Rosebird Centre during November 2019, the sword was added shortly afterwards
}}
Studley
| owner = Studley Parish Council
| notes = A centre piece for Studley Island. Uses the heritage of the town's needle making industry
}}
